;哈马斯已经为加沙地带的长期战争做好了准备，并相信这可以长期阻碍以色列的前进两名接近该组织领导层的消息人士称，这足以迫使其主要敌人同意停火。

;

;据知情人士称，统治加沙的哈马斯已经储存了武器、导弹、食品和医疗用品，由于情况敏感，他拒绝透露姓名。知情人士告诉路透社，该组织相信其数千名战士能够在巴勒斯坦飞地深处挖掘的隧道城市中生存数月，并通过城市游击战术挫败以色列军队。

;

;最终，哈马斯相信国际压力消息人士称，随着平民伤亡不断增加，以色列结束围困可能会迫使双方停火并通过谈判达成解决方案，该武装组织将做出切实让步，例如释放数千名巴勒斯坦囚犯以换取以色列人质。

;

;据四名哈马斯官员、一名地区官员和一名哈马斯官员称，该组织已在卡塔尔调解的间接人质谈判中向美国和以色列明确表示，它希望强制释放囚犯以换取人质。熟悉白宫想法的人士。

;

;从长远来看，哈马斯表示希望结束以色列对加沙长达 17 年的封锁，并停止以色列定居点扩张以及巴勒斯坦人认为的高压手段以色列安全部队在耶路撒冷最神圣的穆斯林圣地阿克萨清真寺采取的行动。

;

;周四，联合国专家呼吁在加沙实行人道主义停火，称那里的巴勒斯坦人“;种族灭绝的严重风险;”。许多专家认为危机不断升级，双方都看不到明确的结局。

;

;“摧毁哈马斯的使命并不容易实现，”约旦前外交部长兼副首相马尔万·穆阿舍尔 (Marwan Al-Muasher) 表示他现在在华盛顿的卡内基国际和平基金会工作。

;

;“这场冲突没有军事解决方案。我们正处于一些黑暗时期。这场战争不会持续很短。”

; >;

;自 10 月 7 日袭击以来，以色列部署了压倒性的空中火力，哈马斯枪手冲出加沙地带，杀死 1,400 名以色列人，劫持 239 名人质。

;

;加沙死亡人数已超过 9,000 人每天的暴力事件都会加剧世界各地的抗议活动，因为超过 200 万加沙人被困在这个狭小的飞地中，其中许多人没有水、食物或电力。以色列空袭袭击了;拥挤的难民营; 周二在加沙杀害了至少 50 名巴勒斯坦人和一名哈马斯指挥官。

;

;以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡发誓要消灭哈马斯，并拒绝了停火的呼吁。以色列官员表示，他们对未来可能发生的事情不抱任何幻想，并指责武装分子躲在平民后面。

;

;前以色列国防军前参谋长丹尼·达农 (Danny Danon) 表示，该国已做好迎接“长期而痛苦的战争”的准备。以色列驻联合国大使和以色列议会外交事务和国防委员会前成员。

;

;“我们知道最终我们将获胜，我们将击败哈马斯，”他告诉路透社。 “问题在于价格，我们必须非常谨慎、非常小心，并了解这是一个非常复杂的城市地区，难以操纵。”

;

;美国表示，现在不是采取行动的时候。卡塔尔大学研究哈马斯的巴勒斯坦国际事务专家 Adeeb Ziadeh 表示，该组织一定有一个长期计划跟踪其对以色列的攻击。<​​/p>;

;“那些在 10 月 7 日进行攻击的人，以其熟练程度、专业水平、精确性和强度，已经做好了长期战斗的准备。齐亚德告诉路透社，哈马斯不可能在没有充分准备和动员起来的情况下进行这样的袭击。

;

;华盛顿预计哈马斯将试图在以色列的街头战斗中陷入困境。熟悉白宫想法的消息人士称，他们对加沙造成了足够严重的军事伤亡，也导致以色列公众对旷日持久的冲突的支持。

;

;尽管如此，以色列官员还是强调了这一点。

;

;这位人士表示，他们向美国同行表示，他们准备对抗哈马斯的游击战术，并承受国际社会对其攻势的批评。消息人士补充说，该国是否有能力消灭哈马斯，或者只是严重削弱该组织，仍然是一个悬而未决的问题。

;

;据该组织的消息人士称，哈马斯约有 4 万名武装分子。他们可以使用巨大的;加固隧道网在飞地内移动< /a>;，长数百公里，深达 80 米，历经多年建成。

;

;周四，加沙武装分子从隧道中出现，向坦克开火，然后又消失在网络中，根据;居民和视频;.

;

;以色列军方表示，Yahalom 特种作战工程部队的士兵一直在与其他部队合作，定位并摧毁隧道竖井，发言人称其为加沙的一场“复杂的城市战斗”。

;

;近几十年来，哈马斯与以色列进行了一系列战争，驻贝鲁特的哈马斯对外关系负责人阿里·巴拉卡表示，哈马斯已逐渐提高其军事能力，特别是导弹能力。他补充道，在 2008 年加沙战争中，哈马斯火箭弹的最大射程为 40 公里（25 英里），但到 2021 年冲突已升至 230 公里。

;

;“在每场战争中，我们都会让巴拉卡告诉路透社。

;

;一位与伊朗支持的黎巴嫩运动真主党关系密切（与哈马斯结盟）的官员表示，经过数周的轰炸，巴勒斯坦激进组织的战斗力基本保持完好。据真主党和哈马斯官员称，真主党在黎巴嫩与哈马斯和伊朗支持的区域网络中的其他盟军派系设有联合军事行动室。

;

;哈马斯被以色列、美国认定为恐怖组织和欧盟，在 1988 年的建国宪章中呼吁摧毁以色列。

;

;在随后的一份名为 2017 年宪章的文件中，该组织首次接受了在 1967 年边界内建立巴勒斯坦国的想法以色列在;六日战争;后声称拥有主权，尽管该组织没有明确承认以色列的存在权。

;

;驻贝鲁特的哈马斯官员奥萨马·哈姆丹表示，10 月 7 日的袭击和正在展开的加沙战争将使巴勒斯坦建国问题重新回到巴勒斯坦问题上。地图。

;

;“这对我们来说是一个机会，告诉他们我们可以用自己的双手创造我们的命运。我们可以以符合我们利益的方式安排该地区的方程式，”他告诉路透社.

;

;以色列和巴勒斯坦权力机构 (PA) 于 1993 年为结束数十年的冲突而达成的《奥斯陆和平协议》碰壁后，哈马斯获得了影响力。内塔尼亚胡于 1996 年首次赢得权力。巴勒斯坦人和美国谈判代表表示，内塔尼亚胡政府多年来拒绝停止在被占领的约旦河西岸修建犹太人定居点，破坏了建立独立巴勒斯坦国的努力。以色列官员过去否认定居点是和平的障碍，内塔尼亚胡目前的极右翼联盟对放弃被占土地采取了更强硬的立场。

;

;一项阿拉伯和平倡议，得到了广泛的国际和阿拉伯国家的一致支持自 2002 年以来一直在讨论中。该计划向以色列提供具有全面外交关系的和平条约，以换取一个主权巴勒斯坦国。

;

;内塔尼亚胡反而选择寻求与以色列建立阿拉伯逊尼派联盟，该联盟由埃及和约旦（以色列于 1979 年和 1994 年与这些国家签订了和平条约）以及阿拉伯联合酋长国、巴林和摩洛哥。在 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击之前，他在美国的斡旋下与沙特阿拉伯进行了会谈，以达成一项具有里程碑意义的外交协议，作为针对伊朗的统一战线，但这一进程后来被搁置。

;

;Muasher，前约旦卡内基部长表示，哈马斯的袭击已经终结了在不与巴勒斯坦人接触的情况下实现中东稳定的任何可能性。

;

;“今天很明显，如果不与巴勒斯坦人实现和平，就不可能实现中东稳定。”该地区的和平。”

;对法院判决的质疑被驳回，2021 年维持原判，迫使该公司开始与政府谈判达成新协议。

;

;新合同，该协议于 10 月 20 日由巴拿马政府签署成为法律，为 First Quantum 提供 20 年期采矿权，并可选择再延长 20 年，以换取巴拿马每年 3.75 亿美元的收入。

;< p>;虽然政府表示新合同提供了比之前合同更好的条款，但巴拿马抗议者不同意。

;

;抗议者表示，该合同对加拿大矿工过于慷慨，并指控存在腐败行为。他们还认为该矿场构成环境风险，要求废除合同并禁止所有新的采矿项目。

;

;巴拿马政府允许该矿商在有争议的合同谈判期间进行运营。它没有评论如果合同被撤销会发生什么。

;

;立法者周五批准了一项禁止新采矿特许权的法案，但这并不影响已经拥有特许权的巴拿马铜矿。尽管如此，矿场的使用寿命可能会受到禁令的影响，因为该法案禁止续签和延长特许权。

;

;如果最高法院认为该合同违宪，矿工的运营也可能受到损害，因为它可能会移动关闭其运营或下令谈判新合同。

;

;巴拿马政府尚未公开表示是否计划将该矿国有化。

;

;当地专家表示，让该国最高层法院对合同有效性的裁决将是解决持续争议的最佳方式，因为依法单方面终止合同可能为国际仲裁打开大门，因为这将被视为巴拿马政府违约。

;< p>;巴拿马最高法院将在未来几天审理针对该合同的各种质疑。

;Republican presidential primary ;candidates; will need to meet relatively stringent polling requirements to participate in the fourth debate in December, the Republican National Committee said on Friday, which could result in a winnowing of the field.

;

;The debate is set to take place in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, on Dec. 6, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

;

;To qualify, candidates will need to receive 6% support in at least two national polls, or both 6% in one national poll and 6% in one statewide poll in Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina or Nevada. Those are crucial states in the nominating process, as they are the first four to select their preferred nominee.

;

;Candidates will also need 80,000 unique donors, and at least 200 donors from each of 20 or more states and territories, the RNC said in a statement.

;

;Traditionally, candidates that fail to make a debate stage lose the attention of the media, voters and donors. For the candidates that make it, a smaller stage will mean more speaking time, giving them valuable exposure in the lead-up to the Iowa caucuses, set for Jan. 15.

;

;As of now, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley appear to be easily meeting the polling threshold. Former tech entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy also would make the stage, considering current surveys, albeit by a narrower margin.

;

;Unless their fortunes improve, US Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum would not make the stage in Alabama.

;

;Former President Donald Trump, who is by far the frontrunner, meets the polling thresholds, but has declined to participate in the debates so far, saying it would be a waste of time given his significant lead.

;

;The ;third Republican debate;, which has a similarly structured polling threshold of 4%, will take place on Wednesday in Miami. Haley, DeSantis, Christie and Ramaswamy will be in attendance. Scott is on the cusp, but has said he has qualified. Burgum appears so far to be short of the threshold.

;;2023-11-03T21:14:58Z;
;;
;;E. Jean Carroll exits the Manhattan Federal Court following the verdict in the civil rape accusation case against former US President Donald Trump, in New York City, US, May 9, 2023. REUTERS/David Dee Delgado;
;

;A federal judge said Donald Trump will face an anonymous jury as it decides how much he should pay E. Jean Carroll for defaming the writer in 2019 by denying that he raped her.

;

;US District Judge Lewis Kaplan in Manhattan said he found "strong reason" to provide special protections for jurors at the scheduled Jan. 16, 2024 civil trial.

;

;He cited the former US president's repeated public criticisms of Carroll and the "extensive media coverage" of her case.

;

;Kaplan also pointed to Trump's conduct in New York Attorney General Letitia James' civil fraud lawsuit against him, where the presiding judge has fined Trump twice for violating a gag order with comments about his clerk.

;

;If juror identities were disclosed, "there would be a strong likelihood of unwanted media attention to the jurors, influence attempts, and/or harassment or worse by supporters of Mr. Trump [and/or by Mr. Trump himself]," Kaplan wrote.

;

;Kaplan said the names, addresses and places of employment of prospective jurors will be kept secret.

;

;Jurors will also be transported together to and from the courthouse and be looked after by US marshals during breaks in the trial.

;

;Neither Carroll, a former Elle magazine columnist, nor Trump, nor anyone else objected to using an anonymous jury, the judge said.

;

;In a lawsuit that began in November 2019, Carroll is seeking at least $10 million over comments Trump made in the White House after she first publicly accused him of raping her in a Bergdorf Goodman dressing room in the mid-1990s.

;

;Trump denied knowing Carroll, said she was not his "type," and said she made up the claim to promote her upcoming memoir.

;

;Another anonymous jury in May ;ordered; Trump to pay Carroll $5 million for sexual assault and defamation in a second lawsuit, after Trump again denied her claims in October 2022.

;

;Trump is appealing that verdict. Both sides are awaiting a decision by the federal appeals court in Manhattan on whether absolute presidential immunity shields Trump from Carroll's first lawsuit.

;

;In September, Kaplan ;ruled; that the jury's defamation findings in May applied to Carroll's first lawsuit, leaving for trial only the issue of damages.

;

;Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican nomination to challenge Democratic President Joe Biden in the 2024 US election despite facing four federal and state criminal indictments. He has pleaded not guilty in those cases.

;

;The case is Carroll v. Trump, US District Court, Southern District of New York, No. 20-07311.

;US President Joe Biden and leaders from Canada, Latin America and the Caribbean on Friday pledged to strengthen the Western Hemisphere's supply chains as Washington works to counter China and stem ;regional migration;.

;

;Biden hosted leaders from Barbados, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Peru and Uruguay and top officials from Mexico and Panama at the White House.

;

;Leaders at the inaugural Americas Partnership for Economic Prosperity (APEP) Leaders' Summit agreed to strengthening supply chains in areas including clean energy, medical supplies and semiconductors. The also vowed to expand regional trade links.

;

;Biden started the meetings with a message of hope despite challenges posed by the Israel-Hamas conflict and the Ukraine war.

;

;He said the summit's goal was to "harness the incredible economic potential of the Americas and make the Western Hemisphere the most economically competitive region in the world," drawing a sharp contrast to China's often-criticized ;lending practices;.

;

;"We want to make sure that our closest neighbors know they have a real choice between debt-trap diplomacy and high-quality transparent approaches to infrastructure and inter-development," Biden said.

;

;The leaders agreed to meet every two years, with Costa Rica to host the next leaders' summit in 2025.

;

;Senior US officials said they hope to reduce the numbers of migrants arriving at the US-Mexico border by expanding economic opportunities for people at home.

;

;Six APEP countries - Costa Rica, Ecuador, Colombia, Peru, Chile and Panama - had offered legal status to millions of people displaced in the Western Hemisphere, one of the officials said. "They have stepped up in big ways and we are stepping up for them," the official added.

;

;Record numbers of migrants have crossed illegally through the US-Mexico border in recent years, with hundreds of thousands of people heading north after traversing a perilous jungle region known as the Darien Gap between Colombia and Panama.

;

;Jason Marczak, senior director of the Atlantic Council's Adrienne Arsht Latin America Center, said the partnership would "set the stage for a new era of US investment in the region." He cited bipartisan support in Congress for more investment after ;supply chain snafus during the COVID-19 pandemic; triggered concerns about over-reliance on China.

;

;US Treasury Secretary ;Janet Yellen hosted a meeting; for the leaders on Friday and said Washington would work with other shareholders to enable a "significant" capital increase for the Inter-American Development Bank's (IDB) private sector arm, IDB Invest.

;

;The United States, Canada, South Korea and Spain are working with the IDB to make $89 million in grants available for countries dealing most with irregular migration, the White House said.

;

;The IDB will also unveil a new financing platform to serve middle- and higher-income countries, potentially mobilizing billions of dollars for investment in renewable energy, US officials said.

;

;Meanwhile, the United States Agency for International Development committed $5 million to help launch an "accelerator" program to support up-and-coming entrepreneurs from the Americas.
